  • 4. Lessons Learned
  • 5. Engage with Us

Related Content:

Below is an overview of the planned blog series â€“ each post focusing on a specific integration topic. Once published, the titles will be linked for direct access:

Integrating SAP EHS in the Public Cloud: Extending Your Existing Landscape Side-by-Side â€“ Guidebook

Part 1: Introduction & OverviewLink
Part 2: Integration of Employees from SAP SuccessFactorsLink
Part 3: Integration of Business Partners & Material from SAP Master Data Governance (MDG)Link
Part 4: Integration of Functional Locations & Equipment from SAP S/4HANA On-Premise SystemLink
Part 5: Extensibility Scenarios & Further ImplementationLink
Part 6: Summary & OutlookLink

 

1. Why is this Integration required?

Integrating employee data from SAP SuccessFactors into SAP EHS Public Cloud is a foundational step for enabling core EHS processes such as Incident Management, Risk Management, and Emissions Management. Instead of maintaining employee data locally within SAP EHS Public Cloud, the system relies on Workforce Person master data replicated from the corporate HR system. This ensures that roles, organizational assignments, and reporting lines remain consistent across the enterprise.

Accurate and up-to-date employee data is essential in Environment, Health & Safety (EHS), as many process steps are people-driven â€“ including incident reporting, assigning investigation responsibilities, approvals, and regulatory documentation. Moreover, EHS integrated workflow functionalities are heavily based on a role and responsibility concept, which depends on the correct assignment of persons within the organization.

In other words: Without employee integration, SAP EHS Public Cloud cannot correctly identify, assign, or document the people involved in an incident or are responsible for EHS tasks.

Architectural Approach - Scope

The highlighted section of the architectural diagram illustrates the scope relevant to this blog post - focusing on the integration of employees from SAP SuccessFactors Employee Central (EC) into SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud.

Note: While this post focuses on the standard integration scenario using SAP SuccessFactors EC as the source, employee master data can also be replicated from other connected HR systems or SAP S/4HANA On-Premise / Private Cloud environments. In such cases, a customized integration flow can be implemented in SAP Integration Suite to transfer the workforce data into SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud. If the integration to the relevant HR system already exists, this step can be skipped.

Reference to User Scenario (A) â€“ Incident Management

In part 1 "Introduction & Overviewâ€, the User Scenario (A) Incident Management at Mike Machineries (chapter 2.1.1) clearly demonstrated why this integration is required:

Scenario Step

Why Employee Integration Matters

An internal maintenance technician is injured

The injured person must be identified as an employee, with job role, organizational unit, and location stored to support injury documentation, reporting and regulatory requirements.

A colleague nearby reports the incident in the system

The system must recognize the reporter as an employee with the correct role and permission to create an incident entry.

A First Aider records medical details in the Injury/Illness Log Entry

EHS needs accurate employee data to identify the certified First Aider and capture their involvement for documentation and accountability.

The Incident Manager is automatically notified and assigned

The Incident Manager must be derived from organizational structures, supervisory relationships, or assigned safety roles maintained in HR.

Corrective and preventive actions are assigned to employees

Task ownership, due dates, approvals, and completion tracking require valid employee master data to ensure accountability and reporting across the organization.

Learnings are shared across sites with operations and safety teams

Up-to-date organizational structures ensure that communication reaches the right target audience for safety awareness and training measures.

Without integrated employee data, the system would not be able to:

  • Identify the injured person, reporter or First Aider,
  • Determine the responsible Incident Manager, or
  • Track assigned corrective actions across organizational units.

This makes the integration of employees from SAP SuccessFactors EC into SAP EHS Public Cloud a mandatory first step before configuring Incident Management.

Note: When implementing Incident Management as shown here in the user scenario, please ensure that scope item 3FP â€“ Incident Management is activated in SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud via Central Business Configuration (CBC) beforehand. This activation is required to enable the Incident Management processes and related configuration in SAP EHS Public Cloud.

While this integration is a prerequisite for Incident Management, it is equally relevant across other EHS use cases such as Risk Management or Emissions Management. In these scenarios, consistent employee master data provides the foundation for assigning roles and responsibilities, managing organizational structures, and ensuring accurate process execution and compliance. Therefore, in the following section, we will take a closer look at the general setup of the employee data integration between SAP SuccessFactors and SAP EHS Public Cloud.

 

2. Prerequisites

To successfully set up the integration scenario for SAP EHS Public Cloud, several prerequisites must be met. These prerequisites ensure that employee master data can be replicated from SAP SuccessFactors Employee Central (EC) to SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud using the predefined integration scenario delivered with scope item JB1 â€“ Maintain Employee Master Data.

Important: Activating scope item JB1 enables the required communication scenarios in SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud, allowing the predefined integration flows in SAP Integration Suite to securely exchange and replicate employee data between the two systems.

To successfully set up this integration scenario, the following prerequisites must be in place:

Tenant Provisioning:

  • SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud tenant
  • SAP SuccessFactors EC tenant
  • SAP Cloud Integration tenant (SAP Integration Suite)

Certificate Setup:

  • Certificates are required only if certificate-based authentication is used for the connection (recommended for productive environments)
  • In our case, Basic Authentication was used for SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud, and OAuth 2.0 SAML Bearer Assertion for SAP SuccessFactors, which requires a Key Pair in the SAP Integration Suite instead of an X.509 certificate exchange.

Administrator Access: Admin users must be available across all three systems:

  • SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud - The administrator should have the template role of SAP_BR_ADMINISTRATOR to allow creation of communication users, systems, and arrangements.
  • SAP SuccessFactors EC
  • SAP Business Technology Platform (BTP) / SAP Integration Suite

Scope Item Activation:

  • Scope item "Core HR with SAP SuccessFactors Employee Central (JB1)" must be activated in SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud system.

Data Requirements:

  • Legal entities in SAP SuccessFactors must match the Company Codes in SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud (Mismatches will lead to replication failures).

Employee Import Restriction:

  • Once employees have been replicated from SAP SuccessFactors EC to SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud, do not manually create or upload the same employee (e.g., via Manage Workforce app). Mixing manually created records with replicated records can lead to data inconsistencies and replication conflicts.

 

3. Technical Integration

This section describes the practical implementation of the employee data integration based on the predefined JB1 â€“ Core HR with SAP SuccessFactors Employee Central scope item. It outlines how workforce data is replicated from SAP SuccessFactors Employee Central (EC) to SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud and highlights the key configuration areas involved in the process.

The JB1 scope item provides the standard integration scenario for workforce data replication and supports related HR data flows relevant for Incident, Risk, and Emissions Management. Accurate and consistent employee master data is crucial for these EHS use cases, as incidents, responsibilities, and corrective actions depend on properly linked workforce information.

Therefore, this section focuses on the JB1 â€“ Maintain Employee Master Data process, which serves as the foundation for all subsequent EHS configurations.

Key JB1 Configuration Areas:

  • SAP SuccessFactors EC Configuration
  • SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud Configuration
  • Integration Package Setup in SAP Cloud Integration
  • Monitoring and Operations

For a detailed documentation, please refer to the official JB1 content in the SAP Process Navigator - SAP for Me.

How to find JB1 setup instructions as a PDF

To view the process visualization, open JB1 â€“ 02 Maintain Employee Master Data in the SAP Process Navigator.

Select "Maintain Employee Master Data" process flow

 

"Maintain Employee Master Data" process flow

 3.1 SAP SuccessFactors Employee Central (EC) Configuration

To prepare SAP SuccessFactors EC for the employee master data replication to SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud, several configuration steps must be completed upfront. In our setup, SAP SuccessFactors was already fully implemented and configured, and our focus was primarily on enabling the integration with SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud. Nevertheless, we have summarized the key configuration steps below to outline the main areas that typically need to be in place to support the JB1 replication scenario. For a detailed, step-by-step configuration, the official SAP Best Practice documentation can be referenced (JB1 setup instructions â€“ chapter 3).

Provisioning Settings in EC

The configuration begins in SuccessFactors Provisioning, where core system settings must be enabled to support employee data replication. This includes activating EC core features, ensuring required language packs are available, and enabling the necessary integration add-ons and OData APIs. These provisioning settings form the technical foundation that allows EC to supply employee data to external systems, including SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud.

Push Replication Setup (Optional but Recommended)

Employee data can be transferred to SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud either through scheduled replication jobs or by using push replication. Push replication enables near-real-time updates and is recommended for scenarios where timely employee data is needed, such as EHS processes. If enables, additional configuration is required to specify which employee changes trigger replication and to define the conditions under which data is pushed to SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud.

Data Model Configuration (HRIS & MDF)

To ensure compatibility with SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud, key elements of the EC data model should be validated and adjusted if necessary. This includes checking HRIS elements for correctness, making sure mandatory fields are maintained, and aligning field properties such as formatting, field length, and data type. MDF objects must also be reviewed for employee-related data elements so that required data can be successfully replicated. Aligning the data model upfront minimizes replication error and ensures that all data transferred to SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud meets the expected structure.

Company Structure and Cost Assignment Alignments

Employee data must be linked to the correct organizational units to enable downstream processes in SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud, including EHS. It is important to ensure that Legal Entities, Business Units, Departments, and Cost Centers are correctly structured and assigned. In some cases, custom fields may be required to support additional mapping between EC and S/4HANA, depending on the companyâ€™s organizational structure. A clear alignment of this data ensures that employees appear in the correct organizational context after replication.

Integration User and Authentication Setup

An integration user with appropriate permissions must be created to allow SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud to retrieve employee data through EC APIs. This includes assigning the required OData API permissions and confirming that the chosen authentication method â€“ basic authentication or certificate-based authentication â€“ is correctly configured. Basic authentication is typically sufficient for testing or demonstration purposes, while certificate-based authentication is recommended for productive environments.

Optional EC Application Settings

In addition to the core configuration steps, EC provides optional settings that can enhance the quality of employee data replicated to SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud. These include settings such as employee information, and contingent worker data. While not mandatory for the integration, these options can enrich the employee profile in the target system.

3.2 SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud Configuration

In addition to setting up SAP SuccessFactors EC, the SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud must also be configured to receive employee master data via the SAP Integration Suite. For this purpose, a Communication Arrangement is required to enable secure data exchange between the systems. In this scenario, the predefined Communication Arrangement SAP_COM_0001 â€“ Employee Integration is used. Activating and configuring this Communication Arrangement enables the necessary inbound API services, allowing the SAP Integration Suite to push employee data into SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud.

Setup illustration of Communication Arrangement SAP_COM_0001

As shown in the illustration above, the Communication Arrangement consists of two key components: an Inbound Communication User and a Communication System.

3.2.1 Communication User

In this integration scenario, an Inbound Communication User was created in the SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud (e.g. user SF_S4HC). This user was used for Basic Authentication in the Communication Arrangement, and its credentials were securely stored later in the Security Material of SAP Integration Suite to enable a safe connection between the systems.

To create the Inbound Communication User in SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud, log in to the Fiori Launchpad as an administrator and open the app â€œMaintain Communication Usersâ€.

Select "Maintain Communication User"

 If no suitable user exists, simply select â€œNewâ€ to create one.

Select New Communication User

Username and password can be freely defined but must be entered later in the Security Material section of the SAP Integration Suite for authentication.

Illustration of our Communication User

These steps align with chapter 5.2 â€œIntegration Credentials Configurationâ€ in the JB1 setup instructions (pages 29â€“30). For more details on using Certificate-based Authentication instead of Basic Authentication, please refer to the corresponding JB1 guide section.

3.2.2 Communication System

The Communication System defines the technical connection between SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud and the external system, in this case SAP Integration Suite. It contains system details such as URLs, authentication methods, and technical identifiers, forming the foundation for all Communication Arrangements that enable secure data exchange. Without a properly configured Communication System, no reliable integration between SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud and SAP Integration Suite can take place.

In our setup, the SAP Integration Suite tenant served as the Communication System. If no system exists yet, a new one needs to be created in SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud. For basic incident management scenarios, this single system is sufficient. However, for additional integrations â€“ such as cost center replication or payroll posting etc. â€“ further configuration might be required (For reference, see chapter 4.1.2 â€œCreate Communication Systemsâ€ in the  JB1 setup instructions, pages 30-31).

To create the Communication System, log in to the SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud Fiori Launchpad as an administrator and open the â€œCommunication Systemsâ€ app.

Select "Communication Systems"

 If no suitable entry is available, create a new system by selecting â€œNewâ€.

Select New Communication System

 Enter a System ID and System Name referring to the Integration Suite tenant and proceed with the set up.

System Setup

After creating the new Communication System entry, additional configuration details must be maintained â€“ including General Data, Technical Data, Log System ID, Business System ID, and the User for Inbound Communication. These parameters define how SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud connects with the external SAP Integration Suite tenant.

For comprehensive configuration guidance, refer to the JB1 setup instructions. In our setup, the Communication System was created with the settings illustrated below.

Illustration of our Communication System (1)Illustration of our Communication System (2)

 3.2.3 Communication Arrangement

The final step in the S/4HANA Public Cloud configuration is to bind the previously created components â€“ the Communication User and the Communication System â€“ within the Communication Arrangement (SAP_COM_0001 â€“ Employee Integration).

Once configured, SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud is ready to receive replicated employee master data from SAP SuccessFactors EC through the SAP Integration Suite. The Communication Arrangement provides the inbound service URLs, which must be stored in the corresponding Integration Flow (iFlow) of the SAP Integration Suite to establish end-to-end communication.

To create the arrangement, log in to the SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud Fiori Launchpad as an administrator and open the â€œCommunication Arrangementsâ€ app.

Select Communication Arrangements

 Then click on â€œNewâ€ to create a new Communication Arrangement.

Create New Communication Arrangement

Choose SAP_COM_0001 as the Communication Scenario.

Assign Communication Scenario

Select Communication Scenario

After that, further setting up configurations needs to be done. Therefore, the before created Communication System will be attached.

Communication Arrangement Setup (Select Communication System))

In our scenario, no additional configuration (e.g. cost center replication, address, or payment information) was required, so these fields remained empty.

Communication Arrangement Setup (Additional Properties))

The Inbound Communication User is automatically populated once the corresponding Communication System is selected. At the same time, the Inbound Service provided the service URL used as the receiver endpoint in the iFlow configuration of the SAP Integration Suite.

Communication Arrangement Setup (Inbound Services)

 3.2.4 Monitoring of Replication Scenarios in SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud

Accurate and timely replication of employee data from SAP SuccessFactors is essential for Incident Management and other EHS processes. Any replication failure can prevent incidents from being assigned to the correct person or role, impacting compliance and operational safety. SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud provides the Message Dashboard app to monitor replication scenarios. Before using it for the JB1 integration scenario, recipients must be assigned in the â€œAssign Recipients to Usersâ€œ app.

Configuration Steps:

1. Open the "Assign Recipients to Users" app in the SAP Fiori Launchpad.

Select Assign Recipients to Users

 2. Verify that your user is assigned with the following details:

  • Namespace: /WFD
  • Recipient Name: WFD_WORKER_INTEGRATION
  • Message Type: Application Error or Technical Error

Check if Recipients are assigned to User

 3. If your user is not listed, add a new entry using your User ID and the details above.

Add New User and assign New Recipient

Enter User ID

Assign Recipients to User

Once recipients are assigned, the Message Dashboard displays all relevant replication messages â€“ including errors, warnings, and successfully processed records â€“ allowing early detection and resolution of integration issues.

Note: To reprocess messages directly from the Message Board, the user must have the SAP_BR_ADMINISTRATOR business role assigned. Without this role, reprocessing is not authorized.

Message Dashboard Overview:

Select Message Dashboard

The Message Dashboard provides a consolidated view of all replication messages for the JB1 scenario:

  • The calendar view indicates daily status (green = no errors, red = errors occurred).
  • Messages can be filtered by date range for detailed analysis.
  • The result list summarizes processed messages per interface (e.g., WFD_WORKER/1), including counts of warnings, technical errors, and successful replications.

This monitoring ensures transparency and operational reliability by allowing administrators to quickly identify and resolve replication issues before they impact EHS processes.

Message Dashboard Overview

3.3 Integration Package Implementation in SAP Cloud Integration

3.3.1 Integration Credentials Configuration

In the previous step (chapter 3.2.3), we created Communication Arrangements in SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud to enable inbound communication from external systems. These arrangements ensure that SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud can safely receive employee master data from the SAP Integration Suite.

Within the SAP Integration Suite, the Integration Flow (iFlow) must authenticate against two endpoints:

  • SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud â€“ for employee master data via SAP Integration Suite
  • SAP SuccessFactors EC â€“ which triggers the replication process when called by the iFlow

For communication with SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud, Basic Authentication was used. The credentials of the Inbound Communication User from SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud must therefore be maintained as Security Material within the SAP Integration Suite. This configuration ensures that the integration flow can authenticate securely when transmitting data between the two systems.

Set up Security Material for Authentication against SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud

For communication with SAP SuccessFactors, the iFlow uses OAuth 2.0 SAML Bearer Assertion, which requires creating a Security Material entry with a Key Pair in the SAP Integration Suite. This setup ensures secure authentication whenever the iFlow retrieves data from SAP SuccessFactors.

The highlighted process flow below illustrates where SAP SuccessFactors is triggered by the SAP Integration Suite:

JB1 Process (Maintain Employee Master Data)

For a detailed step-by-step guide on setting up OAuth 2.0 SAML Bearer Assertion and Security Material in SAP Integration Suite, refer to this SAP Community Blog.

3.3.2 Copying Integration Packages

SAP provides preconfigured integration content for scope item JB1 as part of the standard best-practice setup. This allows a straightforward configuration process, since you can simply copy the predefined package into your own workspace. For our scenario, the following integration package was required:

  • SAPSuccessFactorsEmployeeCentralIntegrationwithSAPS4HANAEmployeeData

The package can be found in the Discover section of the SAP Cloud Integration workspace. Once copied, it includes all necessary Integration Flow (iFlow) required for employee master data replication between SAP SuccessFactors EC and SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud.

In the next step, we will configure these iFlows to establish the data exchange process.

Search for Integration Package in SAP Integration Suite

Copying the Integration Package

 

(These steps correspond to chapter 5.3 â€œCopying Integration Packagesâ€ (pages 55â€“56) in the JB1 setup instructions.)

3.3.3 Integration Package Configuration

Configuring Employee Master Data Replication Integration Flow (iFlow) for Initial Full Load:

After copying the integration package into your workspace, the first configuration step is the Initial Full Load. This ensures that all relevant employee master data from SAP SuccessFactors EC is replicated into SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud before any delta update occurs.

Why this is important: Accurate and up-to-date employee master data is essential across all EHS use cases, as it ensures that roles, responsibilities, and organizational structures are consistently reflected in safety and compliance processes. This is particularly critical for Incident Management, where incidents must be linked to the correct employees and supervisors. Without a complete initial load, subsequent data updates cannot be processed reliably.

Key Actions:

1. Set the Timer to Run Once: In the iFlow configuration, choose Run Once for the initial execution. This triggers a one-time full replication of all employee master data.

iFlow Settings for Timer

Note: After the initial load is complete, switch the timer to Schedule to Recur for delta replication.

Why is this needed? Because the initial load only runs once. If you leave the timer unchanged, no further updates will be replicated. By switching to a recurring schedule, you enable delta replication, which keeps employee data continuously up to date.

2. Configure Receivers: Next, open the iFlow and click â€œConfigureâ€. Two recipients must be set up:

iFlow Select Configure

  • SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud Receiver: Use the details from Communication Arrangement SAP_COM_0001. While Certificate-based Authentication is recommended for productive environments, Basic Authentication can be used for test setups. Enter the service URL of SAP_COM_0001 as the address of the receiver. 

Set up Receiver for SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud

  • SAP SuccessFactors Receiver: Configure OAuth 2.0 SAML Bearer Assertion for secure API calls. The address can be taken from the JB1 setup instructions (page 57). The Credential Name here is the same as the Security Material created in chapter 3.3.1.

Set up Receiver for SAP SuccessFactors

 3. Adjust Core Parameters

  • Set Initiate_Full_Load = TRUE for the initial run (reset to FALSE afterwards)
  • Define Company Codes and Workforce Type
  • Set the Full_Transmission_Start_Date to include all relevant employee records

Once deployed, the iFlow performs a complete replication of employee master data. This step establishes the foundation for all ongoing delta updates and ensures that EHS processes consistently reference the correct workforce context.

(These steps correspond to chapter 5.4.1 â€œConfiguring Employee Master Data Replication iFlow for Initial Full Loadâ€ (pages 56â€“59) in the JB1 setup instructions.)

Configuring Employee Master Data Replication Integration Flow (iFlow) for Delta Replication:

After the initial full load has established the basic dataset in SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud, the next step is to enable delta replication. This ensures that any changes in SAP SuccessFactors, such as new hires, terminations, or updates to employee information, are continuously synchronized with S/4HANA Public Cloud.

Why this is important: Delta replication plays a key role in keeping employee master data current across all EHS use cases. Accurate and timely workforce is essential not only for Incident Management, but also for other processes like Risk- or Emission-Management, where employee roles and organizational responsibilities drive compliance and reporting accuracy. Without a delta replication, the system would remain static after the initial load, leading to outdated information and potential inconsistencies. By enabling the delta replication, updates are processed incrementally, reducing system load and improving overall efficiency.

Key Checks before Deployment:

To activate delta replication, ensure the following settings are applied (as mentioned in the initial load configuration):

  1. Timer: Set to Schedule to Recur with an appropriate frequency (e.g., every 10 minutes between 00:00 and 24:00).
  2. Parameter: Set Initial_Full_Load = FALSE to switch from full load to incremental updates.

All other configuration steps remain the same as for the initial load.

Result: Once deployed, the iFlow performs incremental updates instead of a full replication, ensuring that SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud always reflects the latest employee master data for EHS and related business processes.

(These steps correspond to chapter 5.4.1 â€œConfiguring Employee Master Data Replication iFlow for Delta Replicationâ€ (pages 60 â€“ 61) in the JB1 setup instructions.)

3.3.4 Reset Existing Delta Sync Configuration

In exceptional situations, it may become necessary to reset the delta synchronization configuration. This option is designed to reinitialize the replication process by clearing the stored delta markers, allowing the system to fetch data as if it were the first replication cycle.

When is a reset relevant?

  1. Correction of inconsistencies: If previous delta runs failed or resulted in incomplete updates, a reset ensures that all changes are captured.
  2. Testing and validation: For scenarios where a fresh replication cycle is required without performing a complete system reset.
  3. Troubleshooting: When resolving integration issues that cannot be addressed through standard delta processing.

By resetting the configuration, the system retrieves data from the earliest defined point, ensuring completeness. However, this approach should be applied with caution, as it can lead to significant data volumes being processed again.

How can the Reset be performed?

  1. Open the SAP Cloud Integration Web UI of your SAP Cloud Integration tenant and choose â€œMonitorâ€ (under Design) from the top-level menu on the left.
  2. In the â€œManage Storesâ€ block, choose the â€œVariablesâ€ tile. The available variables are displayed in the Global Data Store.
  3. To reset a replication scenario, delete the corresponding variable(s) from this list by choosing the â€œDeleteâ€ button next to the variable(s). The delete button for each variable is on the right side of the variable table in column â€œActionsâ€. The table below specifies the variable name(s) of the variable(s) which needs(s) to be deleted to reset the delta sync configuration for the replication scenario / corresponding Integration Flow (iFlow).

(These steps correspond to chapter 5.5 â€œReset Existing Delta Sync Configurationâ€ (pages 69 - 70) in the JB1 setup instructions.)

3.4 End-to-End Monitoring of Employee Master Data Replication

Monitoring is a critical part of ensuring that employee data replication runs smoothly across all systems involved in the JB1 integration scenario. Accurate employee data is the foundation for all EHS processes, as many scenarios â€“ such as incident tracking, risk assessments, and regulatory reporting â€“ depend on reliable workforce information. Inaccurate or incomplete replication can disrupt these processes and impact compliance or operational efficiency.

3.4.1 Monitoring Across Systems

Employee Master Data Replication involves three layers:

  • SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud (Inbound Monitoring): As described in chapter 3.2.4, inbound replication is monitored using the Message Dashboard (AIF Monitoring). This allows administrators to review message statuses and reprocess failed messages if required.
  • SAP SuccessFactors Employee Central (Source Monitoring): In SAP SuccessFactors, replication activity can be monitored using the SFAPI Audit Log, which displays outbound replication calls and related processing information. While this functionality is available, it is not covered in detail here.
  • SAP Integration Suite (Middleware Monitoring): The SAP Integration Suite ensures that data flows correctly between SAP SuccessFactors and SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud. Monitoring focuses on the integration flow status, message processing, and error handling within the middle layer.

3.4.2 Monitoring in SAP Integration Suite

SAP Integration Suite provides several tools to track and manage integrations flows:

1. Navigate to Manage Integration Content: Navigate to Monitor > Manage Integration Content to verify that the Integration Flow (iFlow) for employee replication is deployed and running. The status Started indicates that the flow is active.

Navigate to Manage Integration Content

 2. Monitor Message Processing: Under Monitor Message Processing, you can view detailed logs for executed messages.

Navigate to Monitor Message Processing

This view shows whether each message has been successfully processed or if any errors occurred.

Example of successfully completed Message Processing

3. Message Status Overview: The Message Status Overview aggregates statistics across all processed messages, including completed, failed and retried executions. This provides a consolidated view of the integration scenario over a selected timeframe and supports quick identification of patterns or recurring issues.

Message Status Overview

(These steps correspond to chapter 6 â€œMonitoring of Replication Scenariosâ€ (page 71) in the JB1 setup instructions.)

 

4. Lessons Learned

Implementing JB1 for employee integration in SAP EHS Public Cloud provided several key insights that are even important for similar projects:

1. Employee Integration is Mandatory: Accurate workforce data is the foundation for EHS processes. Without it, Incident Management cannot correctly identify the involved people, assign responsibilities, or ensure compliance.

2. Initial Load is Critical: A successful initial replication establishes the baseline for all subsequent updates. Any errors at this stage can lead to inconsistencies throughout the system.

3. Delta Replication ensures Timelines: Regular updates are essential to reflect organizational changes such as new hires or role adjustments. Without delta replication, the system remains static and operational risks increase.

4. Reset Delta Sync is a Fallback, not a Routine Step: This option is useful for correcting inconsistencies or re-initializing data during testing. However, it should be applied cautiously due to the potential for large data volumes.

5. Monitoring is Essential for Operational Reliability: Continuous monitoring of replication flows prevents disruptions. Tools like AIF monitoring in SAP S/4HANA and Execution Manager in SuccessFactors proved invaluable for early error detection.

6. Authentication Strategy Matters: While Basic Authentication is acceptable for demos or test environments, certificate-based authentication is strongly recommended for production to ensure security standards.

7. Organizational Data Alignment is Key: Mismatches between legal entities and company codes were identified as a common source of replication errors. Early validation avoids downstream issues.

8. Demo vs. Production Considerations: Simplifications used in demos (e.g., Basic Auth) needs to be adapted for production environments to ensure compliance and robustness.

9. Optional Data Can Become a Blocker: Missing or incorrect optional fields, such as bank details, can prevent successful replication. These fields should be validated early in the process.

 

5. Engage with Us

To follow the series, make sure to subscribe to the SAP EHS Public Cloud blog tag.

We welcome your thoughts and feedback in the comments!

Acknowledgements

This blog post series is the result of close collaboration within our EHS implementation team. I would like to express my sincere appreciation to my colleagues, whose expertise, insights, and project experience significantly contributed to the depth and quality of this guide.

A special thank you goes to:

  • @Westphal

  • @kanwal_singh
  • @Suraj_Ashray1 

 Their contributions were instrumental in shaping the content of this blog post. I am truly grateful for their collaborations and support.

entry.title: Skills Architecture Playbook: 10 Design Decisions with Talent Intelligence Hub that Define Success !
entry.content:
The shift towards a skills-based workforce is picking up speed, and this transformation lives or dies on one thing: your skills architecture, the foundation that defines:

  • how skills are structured,
  • how they are governed,
  • how they flow through your HRtech landscape, and
  • how employees, managers, and admins actually experience them.

Whatâ€™s happening -
Most organizations jump straight into â€œskills projectsâ€ without stopping to define the design decisions that truly matter! I have seen SAP SuccessFactors customers engaging with different HRTech or Skills vendors separately, rather than as a coherent group. The result? Duplicate skills across systems, messy job profiles, confused employees, frustrated managers, and governance models held together with duct tape.

Think of this blog as your Skills Architecture Playbook: the 10 decisions every company must get right to build a clean, future-proof foundation with Talent Intelligence Hub. These decisions will shape everything from AI models and inference reliability to employee growth journeys and manager adoption.

If youâ€™re implementing TIH, planning a Skills Transformation, or just trying to bring order to the skills chaos, this guide is for you.

Letâ€™s get into the decisions that define your success.

Leading Practice Skills Architecture with Talent Intelligence Hub

Hereâ€™s a leading practice approach for designing a Skills Architecture with TIH at its core. Open Skills Ecosystem (OSE) partners help augment and complement customers' internal data, creating a high-quality skills foundation that brings together market skills data, job and work insights, and people attributes.

Once standardized in Talent Intelligence Hub and enriched with employee and organizational master data from SuccessFactors, this unified skills intelligence can be delivered through Career and Talent Development (CTD) as the experience layer for every persona -employees, managers, HR, recruiters, and leaders.

I had shared this diagram in my session at SuccessConnect and have further explained it in my podcast. Give it a listen -  Art of the Possible - Episode 1 - Skills-based Transformation - Talent Alchemy Podcast series

This is how you bring a skills-based transformation concept to life.

1. Choose Your System of Record: Where Does Job & Skills Truth Live?

Everything starts with a single question: Where does the truth sit? 

For job architecture and skills governance, SAP SuccessFactors Talent Intelligence Hub should be your system of record and governance layer.

Hereâ€™s how it breaks down:

TIH + JPB = Your Master Foundation

  • Job Families
  • Job Roles
  • Job Profiles
  • Skills Library
  • Skills tagged to roles and profiles
  1. JPB holds your job architecture. 
  2. Open Skills Ecosystem partners enrich your skills library.
  3. TIH governs and standardizes everything.

Get this foundation right, and the rest of your skills strategy becomes infinitely easier.

2. Standardize Skills in the Attributes Library with AI Skills Standardization

Once you know where the truth lives, the next step is: What does that truth look like? The Attributes Library in TIH is your governance layer for all skills master data.

It helps you:

  • Maintain a clean, unified skills library.
  • Standardizes the Skills data into one common language. 
  • Manage lifecycle states (active, deprecated, standardized)
  • Standardize proficiency scales

Your Open Skills Ecosystem partner sends business- and industry-relevant skill data into TIH, where you standardize it.

This avoids:

  • Duplicate skills
  • Confusing naming conventions
  • Skill inflation
  • Random â€œHR-createdâ€ one-off skills

This is your quality control engine.

Check out my Talent Alchemy Bits and Bytes segment, where I talked about Skills Standardization. 

3. Decide How Skills Will Be Validated

If thereâ€™s one thing employees love, itâ€™s adding skills. If thereâ€™s one thing managers loveâ€¦ Itâ€™s being skeptical of those skills. Validation matters!

You need to decide: 

Who validates the skills?

  • Employee?
  • Manager?
  • Both?
  • Or does it depend on the skill type?

Whatâ€™s the sequence?

  • Employee declares â†’ Manager approves
  • Manager nominates â†’ Employee confirms
  • System infers â†’ Employee validates â†’ Manager approves

Consistency is key.

Which system is the system of record for validation?

TIH/Growth Portfolio or your OSE partner?

Either worksâ€”just donâ€™t let both do it independently. Thatâ€™s how data chaos is born.

4. Define Your Skills Signals Strategy

Skills come from everywhere. Projects, learning, bots, assessmentsâ€¦ even legacy tools that are somehow still alive. Your rule of survival:  SAP SuccessFactors Growth Portfolio should be the master system of record for all employee skill interactions.

That means:

  • Employees view and update skills here
  • Managers make decisions here
  • HR governs here
  • Partners feed into here

Other systems can contribute, but they canâ€™t own the truth

5. Choose What Skills You will Infer and from Where?

Skill inferencing is magicalâ€¦ unless it pulls the wrong signals. You need to define:

What external sources can infer skills?

  • Project systems
  • Legacy HR/LMS tools
  • External learning platforms
  • Gig/mobility platforms
  • Assessment vendors

How will you judge quality?

Set thresholds such as:

  • Evidence required
  • Confidence level
  • Relevance to job or industry
  • Duplication rules

Which SF processes continuously infer skills?

  • Learning completions
  • Internal gigs
  • Performance achievements
  • Career development activities

A thoughtful inferencing strategy prevents â€œnoise skillsâ€ and keeps your profiles trustworthy.

6. Decide Where Employee Skills Data Should Flow

Once an employeeâ€™s skills are updated and validated, where does that data go?

Typical downstream consumers include:

  • Recruiting
  • Learning
  • Opportunity Marketplace
  • Workforce planning
  • Career & succession tools
  • Assessment vendors
Important: "If you have multiple skills-enabled vendors (LMS, recruiting, assessment tools), Growth Portfolio remains the master. Application partners consume standardized data; they donâ€™t manage it. This keeps your ecosystem clean and consistent."

7. Define How the Skills Taxonomy Will Be Propagated

Your skills taxonomy flows outward from TIH into the rest of the ecosystem.

TIH is your:

  • Skills system of record
  • Job architecture governance tool
  • Standardization engine
  • Master metadata source

If you use multiple Open Skills Ecosystem (OSE) partners:

Pick ONE to be your skills architecture provider. Why?

Because multiple skills dictionaries = chaos.
One dictionary + TIH governance = sanity.

8. Design the Employee Experience (Growth Portfolio and..)

Employees are the heart of your skills ecosystem. Decide:

How much ownership do they have?

  • Full self-declaration
  • Only inferred skills
  • Only validated skills
  • Only view or able to manage skills
  • A blended model

What should they see?

  • Validated skills
  • Inferred skills
  • Critical or core skills
  • Skill gaps

How guided should their experience be?

  • Single entry inside SuccessFactors
  • Some interactions inside partner tools
  • Or a completely unified Growth Portfolio experience

The goal?
Keep it simple, intuitive, and aligned to growth, not admin work.

9. Design the Manager Experience (Teams View and...)

Managers are where skills turn into results, development, mobility, and readiness. You need to define:

How much oversight managers have: Do they validate? Approve? Only for critical skills?

How deeply do skills feed talent decisions

Should they use skills to:

  • Recommend learning
  • Suggest gigs
  • Nominate for roles
  • Support succession plans
  • Plan team capabilities

What feedback loops they own

After:

  • Projects
  • Assignments
  • Reskilling initiatives

Manager feedback becomes key evidence for skill proficiency.

10. Design the Admin Experience (Governance, Analytics, and ...)

Admins run the heartbeat of your skills ecosystem. Define:

Who owns the skills library?

  • HR COE?
  • Talent?
  • Learning?
  • A cross-functional governance team?

How partners integrate

External vendors must feed into Growth Portfolio without duplicating or reinventing your skills.

What KPIs HR will track

Some examples:

  • % validated critical skills
  • Internal fill rate
  • Mobility rate
  • Skills coverage vs. demand
  • Time-to-proficiency
  • Learning-to-skills conversion

Conclusion: Your Skills Architecture Is Your Future

Building a skills-based organization is not about collecting skills, itâ€™s about creating a system of truth, a system of intelligence, and most importantly, a system of experience that employees and managers trust.

  • Talent Intelligence Hub gives you the governance layer.
  • Growth Portfolio with CTD (Career & Talent Development solution) provides the experience layer.
  • Your open ecosystem partners give you the enrichment layer.

But your design decisions tie it all together.

Get these decisions right, and skills become the engine behind: talent mobility, workforce agility, learning personalization, internal career growth, and more. Get them wrong, and youâ€™ll spend months reconciling data, chasing inconsistencies, and wondering why adoption is low.

With Talent Intelligence Hub at the center and these 10 decisions guiding your journey, you can build not only an architecture, but a future-ready, human-centered skills ecosystem that actually works.

entry.title: Implications of Functional User license for Contingent workers when using onboarding
entry.content:
In this article we will discuss how a contingent worker is hired as an employee via SuccessFactors Onboarding and how this may affect the functional user license in SuccessFactors.

There are number of ways a user in SuccessFactors Employee Central can be a functional user:

  • They do not have access to SuccessFactors platform i.e. no login permissions in RBP.
  • They are seasonal worker with a length of service lest than 1 year.
  • Their details are mastered in an external HRIS.
  • They are contingent worker.

The full and functional user license only applies to SuccessFactors Employee Central.

A contingent worker will always be a functional user whether they have access to SuccessFactors platform or not.

In the scenario where you have a contingent worker who is â€˜convertingâ€™ to an employee, this requires a termination and a hire record.  If you initiate onboarding for the contingent worker, they will complete their onboarding record for their new â€˜employeeâ€™ record by switching the employment profile switcher.  Clearly for them to do this they will need access to SuccessFactors.  If they do not have access to SuccessFactors and access is given this WILL NOT switch them to a â€˜full user licenseâ€™ as they are a contingent worker, and all contingent workers are classified as functional users.

entry.title: SuccessFactors Org Design: When to Go Standard, Custom, or Keep It Simple
entry.content:
Not every day does a SuccessFactors consultant get to play detective with organizational structures. Usually, businesses handle the heavy lifting of aligning their data to SuccessFactors (SF) org units. But recently, I got a chance to consult on this very topicâ€”and wow, it made me think hard about one question:

When do we create a child object in the org unit vs. a custom object vs. just a field in Job Info?

Org Structures: More Than Just Fancy Boxes

For most large organizations, the classic three-level hierarchyâ€”Business Unit > Division > Departmentâ€”is like wearing a one-size-fits-all T-shirt. It works for some, but for global companies with multiple countries and quirky local structures, itâ€™s a tight squeeze. Each country lead might have their own flavour of hierarchy. But we donâ€™t want to go wild and create a spaghetti org chart with endless layers. Complexity is not our friend here.

So, before we start harmonizing data and designing the â€œto-beâ€ org structure, we need to ask:

Whatâ€™s the purpose of the org structure in SuccessFactors?

Where do we use SF Org Structure?

  1. Permissions
    • Org units act as filters. Example: Give Sales folks access to certain features while keeping HR out of the party.
  2. Reporting
    • It shows how your company looks on paper (or screen).
    • Filters help too. Example: â€œHow many HR employees left the Organization last year?â€
  3. Legal & Compliance
    • Some countries require managers to be from the same country. Org structure helps enforce this rule with matching the position hierarchies to Org Structure and by managing matrix relationships in position hierarchy.
  4. Integration Touchpoints
    • Org units flow into S/4HANA and Employee Central Payroll (ECP) if integration is in scope.
    • They can also sync with other downstream systems.

 

Harmonize the Data

Before we dream of a perfect org chart, we need to group data logically across countries. Can we streamline it? Once we know what we have, we can decide how many layers we need. Letâ€™s say we need five levels. Now comes the million-dollar question:

Do we create child divisions and departments, a custom org unit, or just store info in Job Info fields?

Option 1: Child Units

Pros:

  • Standard configurationâ€”no extra setup.
  • Easy to maintain and works with standard templates.

Cons:

  • Visualization shows five levels, but employee assignment supports only three levels.
  • Child units appear twice in the org chart (yes, thereâ€™s a workaround, but itâ€™s extra effort).
  • Reporting still works, but permissions need creative filtering.

Case Study: Retail beverages company

They opted for a simple 3 level structure to manage Org hierarchy and managed to create custom fields to drive Talent Grouping.

Option 2: Custom Org Unit

Pros:

  • Can extend the structure to four levels.
  • Employees can have four-level assignments.

Cons:

  • Not standardâ€”requires configuration effort.
  • Does not appear as a standard permission filter.

Case Study: Logistics and Supply chain company with multiple subsidiaries

  • They first considered adding child departments but realized employees could only be assigned to three levels creating difficulty in identifying the multiple subsidiary units.
  • They opted for a custom org unit, enabling four-level assignments for better reporting.
    Result: Balanced complexity with functionality.

Option 3: Custom Field in Job Info

Ask yourself: Do we really need extra layers if they donâ€™t serve multiple purposes? For example:

  • If itâ€™s just for payroll grouping, why not reuse PayScale Group?
  • If itâ€™s for benefits or location grouping, add a custom field like â€œBenefit Groupâ€ or â€œLocation Area.â€

This approach is simple, flexible, and avoids unnecessary complexity.

Case Study: Multinational Hair care company

A multinational hair care company had employees acquired out of M&A. Instead altering their Org structure, they created a custom field in Job info to flag them for time related groupings (such as different annual leave quota for them).

  • Result: Simple, flexible, and avoided unnecessary hierarchy.

Final Thoughts

Before adding layers like an onion, ask: Does this serve a real business purpose? If yes, go for it. If not, keep it simple. Sometimes, a custom field beats a fancy org chart.

What do you think? Have you faced similar challenges? Drop your thoughtsâ€”I would love to hear your take!

entry.title: SuccessFactors 2H 2025: Seamless Talent Data Transfer from Inactive to Active Employment
entry.content:
Whatâ€™s New?

SAP SuccessFactors introduces a powerful enhancement via the new feature Transfer Individual Talent Data from Inactive to Active Employment:

"Transfer Individual Talent Data from Inactive to Active Employment"- This enhancement introduces a person-centric Manage Individual Talent Data Transfer capability, enabling administrators to seamlessly migrate an employeeâ€™s complete talent history in a single action from inactive to active employment. 

Key Highlights

The new functionality inaugurates an advanced functionality within SAP SuccessFactors Performance & Goals, facilitating the seamless migration of an individualâ€™s complete historical talent data from an inactive employment record to their current active employment in a single, streamlined process. This ensures uninterrupted continuity of performance insights across employment transitions, thereby supporting holistic talent management and organizational agility.

Business Use Cases

When an employee permanently relocates to a host country, a new user ID is assigned to them. During this transition, the employee requires access to their talent data originally associated with their home country user ID. In such instances, administrators or HR personnel can facilitate the seamless transfer of the employeeâ€™s talent data from their inactive home country user ID to the newly active host country user ID, ensuring uninterrupted access to their complete talent history.

How to Configure

  1. You have enabled Employee Central to manage multiple employments.
  2. You have enabled at least one of these modules: Goal Management, Performance Management, 360 Reviews, Continuous Performance Management, Calibration, and Career Development.
  3. You have enabled the data transfer tool through Admin Center > Company System and Logo Settings > Enable Individual Talent Data Transfer from Inactive to Active Employment.
  4. You're recommended to configure employment differentiators, which helps you identify and select the correct source and target employments for data transfer.
  5. The subject person for data transfer should have at least one inactive employment and one active employment.
  6. To ensure the person's new employment and their stakeholders have the permission to access the transferred data, make sure module-specific permissions are correctly granted with right target population. For details, refer to the Guide topic in the Related Information section.

Role-Based Permission Pre-requisites

  1. With the Administrator Permissions --> Manage System Properties --> Company System and Logo Settings permission, you have enabled the data transfer tool through Admin Center --> Company System and Logo Settings --> Enable Individual Talent Data Transfer from Inactive to Active Employment.
  2. You have the Administrator Permissions --> Manage Individual Talent Data Transfer permission to use the tool.
  3. You have the User Permissions --> General User Permission --> User Search permission for the specified target population.
  4. You have the Administrator Permissions Manage Hires --> Include Inactive Employees in the search permission to select inactive employments as the source for data transfer.
  5. You have the permission to view the status, title, and assignmentDisplayHeader (if you've configured the fields in the data modal) under User Permissions Employee Data   Employee Profile.
  6. The subject person for data transfer should have at least one inactive employment and one active employment.

Why It Matters

This important enhancement of Person-centric talent data transfers benefit organizations by ensuring uninterrupted access to comprehensive employee performance histories across transitions, enhancing data accuracy, reducing administrative workload, supporting compliance, and fostering agile, informed talent management. This approach strengthens employee engagement and retention by maintaining a continuous, unified view of their development and achievements.

Take Action

The transfer of talent data from an inactive to an active user ID can be tailored to align with your organizational requirements, enabling enhanced process agility and significantly reducing administrative burden through this advanced feature.

Start configuring today and experience the difference!
